title-group.article-title: Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) for catatonia: delay may be risky

body.p: We read with great interest the superbly presented case “The use of electroconvulsive therapy in a patient with juvenile systemic lupus erythematosus and catatonia”.1 The authors comprehensively document the patient’s complex medical and neuropsychiatric illness. The case highlights how difficult the ultimate diagnosis of catatonia may be in a non-psychiatric patient. Despite appropriate management, recommendation for electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) was delayed for three months as is often the case. Such delay is not without risk; catatonic patients are predisposed to a wide variety of medical complications, many of which may be serious, even lethal. As early as 1977 Regestein et al. described fatal outcomes in two patients with catatonia, warning that catatonic stupor can “lead to fatal complications, and aggressive medical and psychiatric therapy is indicated”.2 As recently as 2012, a death due to the delayed implementation of ECT in a catatonic patient has been reported.3 Other medical complications that have been reported in association with catatonia include pulmonary emboli,4 pneumonia,5 and contractures.6 The full spectrum of medical complications in catatonic patients has recently been reviewed.7 “Malignant catatonia” refers to a particularly severe syndrome of catatonic features and autonomic instability that has a high mortality rate if not aggressively treated; ECT may be considered the treatment of choice for this condition.8 Mon et al. described the use of right unilateral (RUL) ECT in their patient, and this is a helpful addition to the literature about the efficacy of this type of ECT. We continue to believe, however, that in urgently ill patients, for whom transient cognitive impairment is a secondary consideration, bilateral ECT at substantially suprathreshold stimulus dosing remains the technique of choice.9 While ECT is rarely recommended for children and adolescents, when appropriate indications are present, there is no reason to consider age an impediment to its use.10 Fortunately for Mon et al.’s patient, a three-month delay did not prevent an excellent outcome; however, we strongly urge early consideration of ECT, when appropriate, to avoid medical complications resulting from prolonged catatonia.
